definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To speak gruffly.
<adjective>
   1. Having a rough, surly, and harsh demeanor and nature.
   2. Hoarse-voiced.
etymology: First recorded in 1525–35; from Middle Dutch grof “coarse”; cognate with German grob

definitionA: dignified propriety of behavior, speech, dress, etc.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. Appropriate social behavior.
   2. A convention of social behavior.
etymology: First recorded in 1560–70; from Latin decōrum, noun use of neuter of decōrus decorous

definitionA: liking or enjoyment of the taste of something.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A pleasant taste
   2. Enjoyment; pleasure.
   3. A quality or characteristic tinge.
   4. (followed by "for") A taste (for); liking (of); fondness.
   5. A cooked or pickled sauce, usually made with vegetables or fruits, generally used as a condiment.
   6. In a wooden frame, the projection or shoulder at the side of, or around, a tenon, on a tenoned piece.
   7. Something that is greatly liked or savoured.
<verb>
   1. To taste or eat with pleasure, to like the flavor of
   2. To take great pleasure in.
   3. To taste; to have a specified taste or flavour.
   4. To give a taste to; to cause to taste nice, to make appetizing.
   5. To give pleasure.
etymology: First recorded in 1520–30; alteration of Middle English reles “aftertaste, scent,” from Old French, variant of relais “remainder, that left behind”; release
First recorded in 1500–10; from Latin alacritāt-, stem of alacritās “enthusiasm, zeal,” equivalent to alacer + -tās- noun suffix ( -ty 2 )

definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A thin, soft muslin.
   2. Marijuana that has been chopped to prepare it for smoking.
   3. A stew of meat, broth, milk, butter, vegetables, and seasonings, thickened with soda crackers.
   4. The gauze used in bookbinding to adhere a text block to a book's cover.
   5. An inferior kind of madder prepared from the smaller roots or the peelings and refuse of the larger.
<verb>
   1. (usually with over) To work (over) mentally; to cogitate; to ruminate.
   2. To powder; to pulverize.
   3. To chop marijuana so that it becomes a smokable form.
   4. To heat and spice something, such as wine.
   5. To join two or more individual windows at mullions.
   6. To dull or stupefy.
<noun>
   1. A promontory.
   2. A snuffbox made of the small end of a horn.
<noun>
   1. Dirt; rubbish
etymology: First recorded in 1815–25; perhaps identical with mull “to crumble, pulverize”; mull 4

definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A cripple.
   2. (rehabilitation, generally self-referential) A person with a disability.
etymology: An Americanism dating back to 1915–20; shortening of cripple

definitionA: a whip or lash, especially for the infliction of punishment or torture.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A source of persistent trouble such as pestilence that causes pain and suffering or widespread destruction.
   2. A means to inflict such pain or destruction.
   3. A whip, often of leather.
<verb>
   1. To strike with a scourge; to flog.
etymology: 1175–1225; (noun) Middle English < Anglo-French escorge, derivative of escorgier to whip < Vulgar Latin *excorrigiāre, derivative of Latin corrigia thong, whip ( ex- 1 ); (v.) Middle English < Old French escorgier

definitionB:
<noun>
   1. Strong desire; passion.
   2. A lecher.
<noun>
   1. A stream or pool in boggy land.
<noun>
   1. A quantity of wood ashes, through which water passes, and thus imbibes the alkali.
   2. A tub or vat for leaching ashes, bark, etc.
   3. A jelly-like sweetmeat popular in the fifteenth century.
<verb>
   1. To purge a soluble matter out of something by the action of a percolating fluid.
   2. To part with soluble constituents by percolation.
<noun>
   1. An aquatic blood-sucking annelid of class Hirudinea, especially Hirudo medicinalis.
   2. A person who derives profit from others in a parasitic fashion.
   3. A glass tube designed for drawing blood from damaged tissue by means of a vacuum.
<noun>
   1. A physician.
   2. (Heathenry) A healer.
<noun>
   1. The vertical edge of a square sail.
   2. The aft edge of a triangular sail.
etymology: First recorded in 1790–1800; probably back formation from lecher

definitionA: to irritate or provoke to a high degree; annoy extremely:
definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To tax the patience of, irk, frustrate, vex, provoke, annoy; to make angry.
<adjective>
   1. Exasperated; embittered.
etymology: First recorded in 1525–35; from Latin exasperātus (past participle of exasperāre “to make rough, provoke”), equivalent to ex- ex- 1 + asper “harsh, rough” + -ātus -ate 1

definitionA: an opaque, ash-colored secretion of the sperm whale intestine, usually found floating on the ocean or cast ashore: used in perfumery.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A solid, waxy, flammable substance of a dull grey or blackish color, produced in the intestines of the sperm whale. It is used in perfumes.
etymology: 1375–1425; < Middle French ambre gris gray amber ( amber ); replacing late Middle English imbergres

definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To load down something with a burden
   2. To restrict or block something with a hindrance or impediment
   3. To burden with a legal claim or other obligation
etymology: First recorded in 1300–50; Middle English encombren, encombre, encomber, from Anglo-French, Middle French encombrer, equivalent to en- prefix + -combrer, verbal derivative of combre “dam, weir,” from early Medieval Latin combrus, from Gaulish comberos (unrecorded) “confluence, bringing together” (compare Quimper, in Brittany, from Breton Kemper ); en- 1, com-, bear 1
example: Two questions that have forever encumbered treatment of intellectual responsibility remain with us.

definitionA: a large retail store, especially one selling a great variety of articles.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A city or region which is a major trading centre; also, a place within a city for commerce and trading; a marketplace.
   2. A shop that offers a wide variety of goods for sale; a department store; (with a descriptive word) a shop specializing in particular goods.
   3. A business set up to enable foreign traders to engage in commerce in a country; a factory (now the more common term).
   4. (by extension) The brain.
etymology: First recorded in 1580–90; from Latin, from Greek empórion “market, emporium,” equivalent to émporos “merchant,” originally “traveler, passenger” ( em- em- 2 + póros “passage, voyage”) + -ion noun suffix of place
